title: Legacies: Kobe Bryant and Impeachment
summary: A reporter's tasteless tweet about the NBA legend, a Senate Republican blunder in forgoing witnesses.. Here is something small but big that happened this week and speaks of a generation gap within journalism. I write from the perspective of having worked the overnight shift at CBS News when I started out, choosing stories off the wires to lead hourly newscasts. I was young, and I sometimes got it wrong in terms of news judgment.

title: Crying Wolf on Impeachment
summary: The whole affair was a series of major fouls. The best outcome is a speedy acquittal.. The impeachment trial of Donald J. Trump is coming down to one big question: Will Democrats, by crying wolf, drown out the more legitimate Republican cry of foul?

title: Brexit May Make Europe Safe for Democracy
summary: The EU is based on the premise that voters can't be trusted. The U.K. has rebuked that idea.. They said it wouldn't happen, but here we are: Britain departs the European Union at 11 p.m. London time Friday. Set aside the wrangling over trade deals, future relationships, immigration and the rest of it. The 52% of voters who chose Leave in the 2016 referendum are getting what they said they wanted, and that means Brexit already is working in the way that matters most.

title: No One Is Safe From Biased Reporting
summary: The New York Times builds a false narrative aimed at discrediting me and tax reform's opportunity zones.. A free and independent press is, and should always be, an impenetrable bulwark of our democracy. "Were it left to me to decide whether we should have a government without newspapers or newspapers without a government, I should not hesitate a moment to prefer the latter," wrote Thomas Jefferson in a 1789 letter. The media's hallowed role, embodied in the First Amendment, assures near-total freedom to report (and even misreport) the news.

title: The Holocaust and Historical Memory
summary: A commemoration at Auschwitz turns into a geopolitical brawl over World War II.. Israel's Yad Vashem recently commemorated the 75th anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz death camp. Dozens of global leaders attended the emotional ceremony, which should have been a unifying moment for Europe and its neighbors. Instead it laid bare deep divisions over historical memory.

title: Trudeau and Trump Team Up on China
summary: They're united on extraditing Meng Wanzhou to the U.S.. President Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau often don't see eye to eye, but they agree that Meng Wanzhou should be extradited to the U.S. Ms. Meng is chief financial officer and deputy chairman of China's Huawei Technologies, the world's biggest manufacturer of telecommunications equipment and second-largest maker of smartphones behind Samsung . It's one of the world's largest providers of 5G technology.

title: The Republican Case for Elizabeth Warren
summary: She has independence and integrity and is no socialist. She just wants the market to work for everyone.. A cardinal rule of politics is don't let your opponents define you. This has been a particular challenge for Sen. Elizabeth Warren, whose critics continue to insist that she is a left-wing radical. I am a Republican and have known and worked with Ms. Warren for many years. She is a capitalist and prairie populist, in the tradition of William Allen White and Teddy Roosevelt. She believes in a market economy. She just wants it to work for everyone.

title: 'Brexit in History' Review: Let's Not Get Together
summary: There has always been a tension: A loose afﬁliation of nation-states vies with the idea of full political union-a United States of Europe.. Today the United Kingdom, after more than three years of turmoil, officially leaves the European Union, though precisely what the separation will mean in practice is hard to say. Beatrice Heuser's "Brexit in History" is thus-for once the phrase is apt-a timely book. It's not really about the Brexit we have been reading about, or at least not directly. Instead, Ms. Heuser, a historian at the University of Glasgow, offers a deep historical dive into the choice that has faced Britain and other countries for centuries: whether to assert the sovereignty of Europe's nation-states or seek some sort of union or confederation among them. Brexit is the latest episode in that unfolding drama.

title: Notable & Quotable: Strong Men
summary: 'One obvious point to note about Trump repudiating the 20th-century ideal of American manhood is that it is no longer the 20th century.'. John F. Harriswriting for Politico, Jan. 30:

summary: Shares, which have been trading near record levels, fell in after-hours trading. Visa Inc. reported record quarterly profit and processed more than $3 trillion in transactions, a record for the quarter, driving a 10% revenue growth.

summary: The U.K.'s exit from the European Union could bring significant changes to the country's sanctions policy. The U.K.'s exit from the European Union could bring significant changes to the country's sanctions policy-a scenario that could complicate compliance for multinational companies.

summary: Conservation groups object to the proposal, say the law forces people to take greater precautions. WASHINGTON-Federal regulators have moved to cement a policy that would remove criminal penalties for companies or individuals who accidentally kill birds.

summary: The Justice Department last year found that prison conditions likely violated inmates' constitutional rights. A panel created by Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey to study the state's violent and overcrowded prison system delivered a range of recommendations Thursday, from boosting corrections department funding to expanding educational programs for inmates.

title: Maduro Gives Economy a Freer Hand to Keep His Grip on Venezuela
summary: Resume Subscription. CARACAS-Venezuela's staunchly socialist leaders, battling to stave off economic collapse and hold on to power, are looking for a little help from an unlikely source: the free market.

summary: Democrats pass bills requiring universal background checks, temporary bans on firearm ownership by people considered dangerous. The Virginia House passed several gun-control bills Thursday, including universal background checks and a "red flag" measure to remove firearms temporarily from people deemed dangerous, moving the state closer to adopting a series of new restrictions.

summary: A surprising boost to operating income revives the stock following last year's beating. The reaction to Amazon.com 's fourth-quarter report Thursday should dispel any notion that earnings still don't matter at the e-commerce giant.

summary: Anna Machkevitch is convicted of failing to comply with a request for documents from the U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office. summary: Spending by city's homeless department is more than $3 billion per fiscal year. New York state should provide more money for rental vouchers to help house the 80,000 homeless people in New York City, lawmakers said Thursday.

summary: Shares have been on a tear since PE firms converted to corporations.

summary: Timothy Shea will serve as the office's top prosecutor on an interim basis. Attorney General William Barr has tapped one of his closest advisers to be the next top prosecutor for the District of Columbia, putting him in charge of the largest U.S. attorney's office and several politically sensitive investigations.

title: Intelsat Bonds Fall on Fears Over FCC Auction Plan
summary: Some bonds hit record lows below 50 cents on the dollar. Satellite operator Intelsat SA's bonds hit record lows Thursday as fears grew that the company will receive far less than expected when the Federal Communications Commission auctions off the C-band spectrum the company uses for its video and radio services.

title: Coronavirus Fears Drive Demand for Face Masks, but Some Experts Doubt Them
summary: Many do little to protect from coronavirus, and even the best have to be fitted and worn properly to have any benefit. As fear about the deadly new coronavirus spreads in China, face masks have disappeared from store shelves and sold out online. At least two Chinese provinces now require them to be worn in public. Factories that make the masks in China are operating 24 hours a day to meet the demand.

title: 'The Assistant': Entry-Level Excellence
summary: Kitty Green's debut dramatic feature follows a young woman working in movie production for an unseen, womanizing boss.. Kitty Green's "The Assistant" reveals its game slowly, with a confidence you wouldn't expect from a debut dramatic feature. For a while it seems to be about nothing more than a day in the life of a dutiful young woman doing mundane chores at a movie production office in Lower Manhattan. Jane (Julia Garner) is a junior assistant to the chairman of the company. Intense and often melancholy, she's surrounded by condescending men who work with, and pander to, the unseen, unnamed, dictatorial and notoriously womanizing boss. The movie's game is opportunistic-we're clearly meant to think of Harvey Weinstein-but also timely and intriguing, a story of sexual abuse in which the predatory behavior, like the abuser, remains unseen behind closed doors. Jane infers it from cumulative evidence, feels it like a toxic cloud. She doesn't mean to be a detective, let alone a crusader. She simply can't leave bad enough alone.

title: 'The Rhythm Section': Downbeat Beat Down
summary: Blake Lively stars as an assassin-in-training seeking vengeance in this one-note drama.. At one point in "The Rhythm Section" my heart went out to the constantly embattled heroine, Blake Lively's Stephanie Patrick. It was the only point, but in a movie as dismal as this one anything that elicits empathy is a plus.

title: Libya's Warring Factions Resume Fighting in Threat to Cease-Fire
summary: Brief lull in fighting after Berlin peace summit ends, as forces-and their foreign backers-jockey for leverage ahead of further truce talks. A resumption in fighting in Libya is threatening to unravel efforts to end a nearly decadelong crisis in the North African country, less than two weeks after foreign backers of the two main warring factions agreed to support a cease-fire there.

title: 'Bombshell': From Battlefields to Impeachments, a Term With Explosive Effects
summary: Descriptions of John Bolton's surprise allegations about President Trump employed a metaphor that goes back to the trial of President Andrew Johnson and beyond. When news leakedout last weekend about the draft of a forthcoming book by former national security adviser John Bolton, the revelation was summed up by one word within countless headlines: "bombshell."

title: In Supreme Court Abortion Case, Louisiana Goes on the Offensive
summary: State argues that clinics shouldn't be allowed to sue on women's behalf in an approach that could change abortion litigation. Facing lawsuits over its abortion laws, Louisiana decided the best defense was offense.

title: Chicago Police to Reorganize to Better Fight Violent Crime
summary: Effort breaks down barriers between patrol, detectives and organized-crime units. CHICAGO-Interim Chicago Police Superintendent Charlie Beck announced a major reorganization of the department to help fight violent crime and meet the requirements of a federal oversight agreement.

title: U.S. Lawmakers Resist Possible Trump Troop Cuts in Africa
summary: Coalition of Democrats, Republicans counter administration proposal to shift U.S. forces from continent. WASHINGTON-With extremist violence surging across a wide swath of Africa, U.S. lawmakers from both political parties are trying to head off a Trump administration proposal to cut American military forces on the continent.

title: Truist Shares Plunge After Bank Says Cost-Cutting Is Slow
summary: The bank said it would reach 30% of its expected merger-related savings in 2020, below its original target of 50%. Shares of Truist Financial Corp. fell 8% after the regional bank said its 2019 merger would take longer to deliver cost savings.

title: States Seek Ruling on Equal Rights Amendment Ratification Deadline
summary: Opponents argue that legal deadlines to approve the ERA expired in 1982 or 1979. WASHINGTON-The last three states to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment sued the Trump administration Thursday, seeking a court order that would write women's equality into the Constitution.

title: Stocks End Day With Push to Gains
summary: Tesla and Microsoft climb, while Starbuck's stock falls. U.S. stocks rose Thursday, brushing off initial losses related to fears about the global coronavirus outbreak.

summary: A Republican member of the Federal Trade Commission voiced skepticism that government antitrust enforcement against big tech companies will lead to better privacy protections for consumers. A Republican member of the Federal Trade Commission voiced skepticism that government antitrust enforcement against big tech companies will lead to better privacy protections for consumers.

summary: The nearly 39-acre aggregate property is close to Mandalay Bay and the new Raiders Stadium. A sizable piece of land on the Las Vegas Strip, once the planned home for the Skyvue Las Vegas Super Wheel, is hitting the bankruptcy auction block.

title: Commodities Slump on Fears Coronavirus Will Dent Chinese Demand
summary: Copper prices have fallen 12% since their recent peak and brent crude dropped to its lowest level in over a year. Commodities including crude oil and copper fell Thursday, extending their recent slide on concerns that the worsening coronavirus outbreak would pare Chinese demand for raw materials.

title: New U.S. Program Aims to Ease Humanitarian Trade to Iran
summary: First transactions completed under channel set up in response to concerns over Iran's economic crisis. summary: Lower interest rates might lead to buildup in future debt, senior official says. The Bank of Canada might need to look beyond its usual two-year horizon when considering the impact of monetary policy on consumer debt and housing markets, a senior official said Thursday.

title: Who Is Kevin Clinesmith?
summary: Even after the collapse of the collusion thesis, good luck getting the press corps interested in allegations of Obama-era abuse.. It was an almost unbelievable story-fit for a spy novel, and among the most disturbing and consequential allegations of governmental abuse in recent history. The alleged abuse went right to the heart of our ability to participate in free and fair elections. But much of the U.S. media seems ready to forget about it.

title: Police Seek Suspect in Killing of Upper East Side Man
summary: Body of 64-year-old man was discovered in his apartment near Central Park. New York Police Department detectives were searching Thursday for a suspect in the killing of a 64-year-old man whose body was discovered in his home near Central Park in Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: Commodities Traders Face Limits on Speculative Positions Under U.S. Proposal
summary: The aim is to prevent speculators from causing unjustified price swings that could hurt consumers. WASHINGTON-Federal regulators on Thursday proposed so-called position limits in markets for commodities such as gold, sugar and crude oil while leaving exchanges with considerable leeway in deciding how to contain speculative bets.

title: 'Grand Horizons' Review: Looking for Laughs at the End of the Road
summary: Bess Wohl's comedy about the breakup of a couple living in a senior community is humorous, but just barely.. New York

title: 'McMillion$' Review: Hamburgling the House
summary: HBO's docuseries looks at how the McDonald's Monopoly promotion was snookered out of $24 million.. In the media maelstrom that erupted around 9/11, a lot of other bad news simply got lost. Pete Sampras was defeated at the U.S. Open. Donald Rumsfeld disclosed that the Pentagon couldn't account for $2.3 trillion in spending. Mariah Carey made her film debut in "Glitter." And the first McDonald's Monopoly trial-which would eventually involve dozens of defendants accused of snookering the nation's biggest hamburger chain out of $24 million-opened in Florida. And was promptly forgotten.

title: 'Tommy' Review: An Outsider on the Beat
summary: Edie Falco stars as the first female chief of the LAPD in CBS's new police procedural.. Edie Falco playing the first female police chief of Los Angeles on a prime-time network crime show was not what anyone expected when the actress was the toast of New York indies in the '90s. Or playing Carmela Soprano in the 2000s. Or Nurse Jackie in the 2010s. "Tommy," however, is almost-almost-exactly what one expects from a prime-time network crime show, namely a glibly scripted, inches-deep drama about an outsider on the inside, resisting entrenched biases and corruption and fighting the power even though, excuse me, she is the power.

title: Luxury Brands Fear Coronavirus Sales Hit
summary: Coronavirus outbreak during holiday shopping period in key market threatens decade-long growth among high-end goods makers. PARIS-The coronavirus outbreak in China is threatening the luxury goods industry with a significant sales hit after a decade of relentless growth fueled by Chinese shoppers.

title: Sustainability Is Part of Good Risk Assessment
summary: Focusing on sustainability helps investors navigate the risks that transcend personal, political or social views to target long-term value.. Your editorials-"Goldman Gets Half Woke" (Jan. 25) and "Larry Fink's Latest Sermon" (Jan. 18)-critical of BlackRock CEO Larry Fink's call to make sustainability a new standard for investing miss the point of what an investment manager's core job is. Yes, the main objective is to generate a return on invested assets, but to meet this objective an investment manager must identify, evaluate and manage risk.

title: Peace Corps in China Gave No Value for U.S.
summary: When I asked what the return on investment was for the U.S. taxpayers, the director (shockingly) had no answer.. In "The Peace Corps Cuts and Runs" (op-ed, Jan. 24), Michael Meyer claims that I, and my colleague Marco Rubio, "don't understand [the Peace Corps'] mission" in Communist China. I can assure you this isn't the case. I would argue it's the defenders of the Peace Corps' presence in Communist China who don't understand and can't explain its mission there.

title: Electoral College Is Better Than Alternatives
summary: Critics of the Electoral College and winner-take-all allocation as "undemocratic" should be careful what they wish for.. The Electoral College wasn't conceived to prevent selection of the president by the popular "rabble" ("Justices to Consider Electoral College," U.S. News, Jan. 18). The only consensus reached by the convention was that the Electoral College was preferable to such alternatives as selection by Congress, state legislatures or popular vote. Lacking a continuous existence, the Electoral College seemingly would be inoculated against its corruption by domestic factions and foreign nations. Fearing that the popular vote would be dissipated among many minor candidates, the framers required the winning candidate to achieve a majority of votes in the Electoral College. Otherwise, the House of Representatives would vote by states to pick a winner. The rise of political parties in the 1790s and the winner-take-all allocation of state electoral votes after 1800 has usually secured electoral majorities for candidates in the more than dozen elections, including Abraham Lincoln's in 1860, in which winners of a plurality of the popular vote fell short of an electoral majority. The exception was the election of 1824 in which John Quincy Adams's selection by the House, despite Andrew Jackson's popular plurality, was saturated by allegations of the very sort of corruption feared by the framers. Critics of the Electoral College and winner-take-all allocation as "undemocratic" should be careful what they wish for.

title: Government Has a Terrible Record Picking Energy Hits
summary: Even if this technology worked exactly as envisioned, it would never be able to compete with other emerging solar technologies.. Your Jan. 17 editorial "The Best-Laid Energy Plans" about the demise of Crescent Dunes, the largest concentrated-solar electric power (CSP) installation in the world, understates the cost to the U.S. taxpayer. In addition to the $737 million quoted, Sandia National Labs spent a couple hundred million developing the underlying technology with its Solar 1 and Solar 2 CPS installations in the Mojave Desert. Combined, taxpayer cost is well over a billion dollars. An additional $140 million was lost by private investors, and $120 million by Nevada taxpayers. All were told this technology was a sure thing.

title: Wage Gainers: $0 to $10.22
summary: What about the formerly unemployed workers going from $0 to the $10.22 median-income wage, joining the 53 million low-wage workers?. Regarding Martha Ross's "All Is Not Well Today for Low-Wage Workers" (Letters, Jan. 23): Statistics can be misleading. What about the formerly unemployed workers going from $0 to the $10.22 median-income wage, joining the 53 million low-wage workers? Ignoring this dilutes the median-income wage increase of these workers.

title: Coca-Cola Posts Higher Sales
summary: The beverage giant will reopen some China factories amid coronavirus outbreak. Coca-Cola Co. reported higher sales that beat analysts' estimates, and said it was working with Chinese authorities to reopen factories that faced extended downtime amid the country's health crisis.

title: President Trump, Michael Bloomberg Release Dueling Super Bowl Ads
summary: Billionaire presidential candidates take their campaigns to year's biggest television audience. Michael Bloomberg will air a Super Bowl ad tackling gun violence, while President Trump will run one about the economy, as the billionaire presidential candidates place their campaigns in front of the year's largest television audience.

title: Remember the Walkman? This Nostalgic Update Improves on a Classic
summary: Attention, tapeheads! This new deck lets you play crackly old cassettes but use your favorite wireless headphones-with questionable success. MORE THAN 40 years after its debut, the Sony Walkman has never seemed more prescient. It triggered the mixtape craze, foreshadowing our deeply personal relationships with playlists. Its foamy headphones help shut out the world, an escape route we increasingly value. And as our obsession with retro tech grows (see also: the Nintendo Classic), cassette tapes are enjoying a cultish renaissance.

title: French Court Overturns Cardinal's Conviction for Failing to Report Sex Abuse
summary: Cardinal Philippe Barbarin's conviction was the first of such a high-ranking Catholic Church official. PARIS-A French appeals court overturned Thursday the conviction of a cardinal who had been found guilty of failing to report child sex abuse-a case that has become a barometer of Pope Francis' efforts to police the Catholic Church's highest ranks.

title: AmerisourceBergen Shuttering Compounding Unit PharMEDium
summary: Resume Subscription. AmerisourceBergen Corp. on Thursday said it is pulling the plug on its PharMEDium Healthcare Holdings Inc. unit after more than two years of regulatory and operational issues at the compounding business.

summary: Crop-science company will reduce reliance on Bayer's genes. Corteva Inc. is ratcheting up a biotech-seed battle with its main rival, Bayer AG , centered on farmers' fight against hard-to-kill weeds.

title: 4 Tourist Attractions You Can't Photograph-from Geishas to Daffodil Hill
summary: You'd think every place would want its tourist sites to go viral. In these four, photo frenzies have led to photo bans or closures. Kyoto's historic Gion neighborhood has long been a must-stop for camera-wielding visitors eager for a sighting of the resident geishas. In the last few years, as tourism in the city has surged, grievances among locals have spiked too. Reportedly, locals complained of tourists chasing geishas to take their photo and trespassing on private property. Last fall, a neighborhood ban went into effect, prohibiting photography on the private roads, alleys and homes near Hanamikoji Street, where many geishas live. Shutterbugs who snap away without a geisha's permission risk a $92 fine.

title: U.S. Economy Heads Into 2020 With Steady Growth
summary: Fourth-quarter growth of 2.1% reflected boost from trade as exports increased; pace of consumer spending slows. WASHINGTON-The U.S. economy headed into 2020 on a solid footing, with growth settling back to the roughly 2% pace that has prevailed during the decade-old economic expansion.

title: Entrepreneur Leila Janah Created Tech Jobs in Africa
summary: U.S.-born daughter of Indian immigrants died this month at the age of 37.

title: An Astros Fan Spent 50 Hours Listening for Cheating
summary: Tony Adams watched 8,274 pitches thrown to Astros hitters during 58 home games from the 2017 season. He logged his results.. Like with many lifelong Houston Astros fans, Tony Adams's first reaction to the news that his favorite baseball team had cheated during the 2017 season was denial. He simply refused to believe that the players he admired so much would stoop to illegally stealing opponents' signs and relaying them to batters in real time by banging on a trash can. It all sounded too ridiculous.

summary: Mortgage Contracting Services, a maintenance provider for foreclosed or vacated homes, has seen business decline in the face of low mortgage-default rates. Near record lows in U.S. mortgage defaults last year spelled good news for homeowners but bad news for one private-equity firm.

title: Impeachment Trial Offers Hints on Where Senators Stand on Witnesses
summary: Both sides press their impeachment case as GOP leaders work to block more testimony. WASHINGTON-Senators wavering on calling new witnesses in President Trump's impeachment trial hinted Wednesday at the factors they were considering, as Republican leaders tried to persuade lawmakers to bring the proceedings to a close later this week without fresh testimony.

title: Early Days for Deutsche Bank's Recovery
summary: Recent results are a good start but the German lender needs to do more to convince investors it is really on track. Deutsche Bank has made a good start out of the blocks, but has a long way left to run.

title: Altria Takes $4.1 Billion Charge on Juul Investment

Altria Group Inc. again slashed the value of its investment in Juul Labs Inc. and stripped down its agreement to provide services to the startup as it weathers mounting scrutiny of the e-cigarette market.

title: Deutsche Bank Posts Big Loss as Overhaul Bites
summary: German lender's efforts to reorganize its operations weighed heavily on its results last year. FRANKFURT-Deutsche Bank AG swung to a €5.3 billion ($5.8 billion) loss in 2019, highlighting the size of its challenge in making itself leaner and more profitable through a sweeping overhaul.

title: What Makes a Wine a Classic?
summary: Our wine columnist makes a case for the canon and shares her list of wines that define what 'classic' means to her. MOST BOOKSTORES have a section marked "classic literature" and another, much larger one where the "fiction" is shelved. What's the difference? A classic work of literature is an accepted archetype of the genre, a book that has withstood the test of time and taste, while fiction is...everything else. I'd define a classic wine in much the same way: an archetype and an ideal. But I recently discovered that to some wine drinkers, classic means something quite different.

title: The Cloud Hanging Over the Super Bowl
summary: Incidents connected with Kansas City's Tyreek Hill underscore the NFL's lingering domestic-violence issue. At any moment, he could torch the San Francisco 49ers secondary and catch a heave from Patrick Mahomes that could determine who wins the Lombardi Trophy.

But despite the publicity, some Houses of the Year don't sell fast.

title: Will We Buy Mostly Vintage Clothes in the Future?
summary: Influential fashion sage Virgil Abloh has predicted that streetwear will die and shoppers will rely increasingly on secondhand clothes. Here, a look at the history of vintage fashion and what's next. WHEN VIRGIL ABLOH recently predicted streetwear's imminent death, his declaration reverberated around the fashionsphere. Streetwear pretty much defines luxury fashion in 2020, so when one of its chief popularizers-the founder of hip label Off-White and influential artistic director for men at Louis Vuitton -pronounced it kaput, the industry's unease was palpable.

title: Maker of Lipton Cools on Tea

summary: Law could halve rents in the most expensive parts of the German capital. title: From MSG Scare to MVP Status: How We Learned to Love Umami
summary: It's what makes miso mouthwatering and Doritos delectable. Some chefs have even taken this savory 'fifth flavor' to extremes. Now a more balanced approach is replacing umami bombs with newly nuanced recipes. SHORTLY AFTER Momofuku Ssäm Bar opened in New York City, in 2006, the chef David Chang began serving a dish there called bo ssäm . The classic Korean recipe calls for boiled pork belly with cabbage leaves and condiments, but in typical Chang fashion, he dialed the flavor up to 11. The Momofuku version starred a pork butt cured overnight and then slow-roasted with a coating of brown sugar and salt that formed a crust the color of mahogany. Diners wrapped ribbons of that roast pork in lettuce along with briny oysters, rice, kimchi, ginger-scallion sauce and ssamjang Ê, a spicy Korean dipping sauce. Word of the off-the-menu stunner rippled sensationally through the local dining scene.

title: The 'Corrupt Motives' Doctrine
summary: Every President equates his re-election self-interest with the public interest. It isn't grounds for impeachment.. title: Fed Holds Benchmark Rate Steady
summary: All 10 members of the central bank's rate-setting panel voted to hold the fed-funds rate in a range between 1.5% and 1.75%.
